mechanism_of_action.References: Lelkin, J.B., Paloucek, F.P., Poisoning & Toxicology Compendium. LEXI-COMP Inc. & American Pharmaceutical Association, Hudson, OH 1998., p. 727
mechanism_of_action.Value: May deplete monoamine neurotransmitters in the central nervous system (inhibition of norepinephrine, dopamine, and serotonin metabolism.

mechanism_of_action.References: Bingham, E.; Cohrssen, B.; Powell, C.H.; Patty's Toxicology Volumes 1-9 5th ed. John Wiley & Sons. New York, N.Y. (2001)., p. V3 p.568
mechanism_of_action.Value: A clue to the mechanism of action of pentaborane in the CNS was found in the inhibition of glycolysis.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Browning, E. Toxicity of Industrial Metals. 2nd ed. New York: Appleton-Century-Crofts, 1969., p. 94
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Acute Exposure/ ... /After/ 4 hr exposure ... /at/ 10.9 ppm for mice and 17.8 ppm for rats. Symptoms were those of acute neurotoxic effect--spasms, tremors, restlessness, and convulsions; corneal opacities appeared after death.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Grant, W.M. Toxicology of the Eye. 3rd ed. Springfield, IL: Charles C. Thomas Publisher, 1986., p. 705
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Acute Exposure/ Dogs exposed to sublethal concentrations... develop characteristic constriction of pupils which appears to be reliable early sign of poisoning.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: American Conference of Governmental Industrial Hygienists.  Documentation of Threshold Limit Values for Chemical  Substances and Physical Agents and Biological Exposure  Indices for 2001. Cincinnati, OH. 2001., p. 1
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Subchronic or Prechronic Exposure/ ...Rats exposed 5 hours/day, 5 days/week for up to 4 weeks to pentaborane 3 ppm (calculated concentration). Hyperexcitability, tremors and decreased body weight were observed following the first week of exposure. ... /Rats, rabbits, monkeys, and dogs were/ repeatedly exposed to pentaborane at calculated concentration of 1 ppm for 4 weeks and at 0.2 ppm for 6 months. Following inhalation exposures at 1 ppm, all species lost weight. Rats were appreciably less active, and the rabbits developed ataxia. At 0.2 ppm, monkeys were apathetic, suffered from anorexia, and appeared anesthetized. There was progressive incoordination, hind limb immobility and muscle tremors in both nonhuman primates and dogs inhaling pentaborane.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Thienes, C., and T.J. Haley. Clinical Toxicology. 5th ed. Philadelphia: Lea and Febiger, 1972., p. 203
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Subchronic or Prechronic Exposure/ ...Centrolobular hepatic necrosis and fatty infiltration in experimental animals indicates injury to liver. In animals there is also decrease in ribo- and deoxyribonucleic acid of liver. ...Animals exposed daily to concentrations resulting in death on seventh day or later have congestion, polymorphonuclear leukocytic infiltration and denuding or metaplasia of mucosa bronchi.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Casarett, L.J., and J. Doull. Toxicology: The Basic Science of Poisons. New York: MacMillan Publishing Co., 1975., p. 220
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Chronic Exposure or Carcinogenicity/ Experimental inhalation exposures of small lab animals... /produced/ CNS damage accompanied by tremor and cramps with degree of excitation... . Chronic exposure (6 months) to vapor concentration of 2.5 mg/cu m resulted in anoxia and weight loss, listlessness, and tremors. Autopsy revealed no serious pathological changes.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Bingham, E.; Cohrssen, B.; Powell, C.H.; Patty's Toxicology Volumes 1-9 5th ed. John Wiley & Sons. New York, N.Y. (2001)., p. V3 p.568
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Chronic Exposure or Carcinogenicity/  In chronic exposures, a 6 month, daily inhalation at 0.2 ppm by monkeys, dogs, rabbits, rats, and hamsters showed ... weight loss, apathy and insensitivity to pain, loss of limb mobility, muscle tremors, and impaired coordination.
